journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Modeling and prediction of tensile modulus and oxygen permeation properties of polyethylene – layered silicate nanocomposites: Factorial and mixture designs

contrib-group.aff: Chemical Engineering Department, The Petroleum Institute, Abu Dhabi

author-notes.corresp: Vikas Mittal, Chemical Engineering Department, The Petroleum Institute, Abu Dhabi. Email: vmittal@pi.ac.ae

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Modeling and prediction of the oxygen barrier and tensile modulus properties of polyethylene nanocomposites through factorial and mixture design methods has been studied. The factorial design was based on factors such as volume fraction of silicate filler, cation exchange capacity of the filler, and number of octadecyl chains in the chemical structure of the filler surface modification. The mixture design had components as polymer matrix, organic modification, and inorganic filler. The case of compatibilized polyethylene nanocomposites was also studied where the components included polymer, organically modified filler, and the compatibilizer. The generated models accurately predicted the properties of nanocomposites as the model equations were validated by the comparison of the predicted values with the experimental results. These models represent an accurate alternative to the conventional modeling methods where a number of assumptions hinder the true representation of the nanocomposite morphology in the model. Moreover, the factorial and mixture models are also straightforward to be modified in order to accommodate any changes in the system. The surface and contour plots could also be generated from the model equations, which pictorially represent the modeling space in which optimization of the nanocomposite properties can be achieved with higher confidence levels.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Polymer-layered silicate nanocomposites are organic–inorganic hybrid materials with at least one dimension of the filler in the range of 100 nm.1–3 Layered silicates, especially montmorillonite, have received significant attention as the inorganic filler to prepare these three-dimensional (3D) nanomaterials owing to the easy swelling of silicate in water leading to 1 nm thick platelets, which can be subsequently surface modified in order to enhance their compatibility with the polymer matrices.4,5 Layered silicate particles with high surface area and geometrical anisotropy lead to increased interactions at the filler–matrix interface bringing about an altogether different morphology, thus, significantly impacting the performance of such composites.6–9

Polyolefins are one of the most widely used commodity plastics with a wide spectrum of applications due to its low cost and good properties.10–12 Development of nanocomposites of these polymers can further enhance the property profiles of these materials, thus, expanding the span of high-end applications. Melt compounding approach has been mostly employed to synthesize polyolefin nanocomposites.13–21 In order to enhance compatibility between the polar filler interlayers and apolar polyolefin matrix, low-molecular-weight compatibilizers like polyethylene grafted with maleic anhydride (PE-g-MA) or polypropylene grafted with maleic anhydride (PP-g-MA) are generally added during melt compounding.13–21 Osman et al.22–24 has extensively reported on such polyethylene nanocomposites with and without the addition of conventionally added compatibilizers. Apart from that, properties of the composites were also studied as a function of different chain density in the filler surface modification molecules, cation exchange capacity (CEC) of the silicate filler, as well as volume fraction of the filler.22–24

Prediction of accurate mechanical and gas barrier performance of the nanocomposites has been a challenge owing to their complex morphology resulting from varying degrees of filler exfoliation and alignment as well as interfacial interactions. For the prediction of mechanical properties, modified Halpin-Tsai model has received special attention owing to better prediction of the tensile properties for a variety of reinforcement geometries.25–28 Similarly, for the prediction of barrier properties, a number of such models have been developed.29,30 However, a number of assumptions like firm bonding of filler and matrix, perfect alignment of the platelets in the matrix, uniform shape, and size of the filler particles (or exfoliation of the filler particles) in the matrix make it very difficult to correctly predict the nanocomposites properties. These assumptions are less realistic specifically in the non-polar polymer matrix composites where the interactions between the organic and inorganic components do not exist. Gatos et al.31 suggested retro-treatment of polymer-layered silicate nanocomposites to consider the dispersion state of filler platelets in predicting the mechanical and barrier properties of the composites. Computational methods like factorial and mixture designs can be another alternative to the existing models as these do not require any assumptions which may not hold true in real composites. Shahabadi et al.32 also suggested using response surface analysis that chain length, packing density, and cation exchange selectivity are important parameters for choosing proper modifier type for the generation of polyolefin nanocomposites.

The present study aims to model and predict the tensile modulus and oxygen permeation properties of polyethylene nanocomposites using factorial and mixture design models. Both compatibilized and non-compatibilized polyethylene-silicate nanocomposites were considered. A previous study dealt with the polypropylene layered silicate models,33 however, owing to the commercial importance of polyethylene, the development of factorial and mixture design for the modeling and prediction of polyethylene-based nanocomposites is needed.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: Design of Experiments (DoE) software from Minitab (version 15) was used to generate factorial and mixture designs. The components for factorial design included volume fraction of the silicate filler, cation exchange capacity of the filler, and the number of octadecyl chains in the ammonium modification. The mixture design was based on components like polymer matrix, organic modification, and inorganic filler. In the case of mixture design for the compatibilizer containing composites, the mixture design was based on components like polymer matrix, organically modified silicate, and the compatibilizer. The experimental data for the modeling purposes was acquired from the literature studies.22–24

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
The factorial and mixture designs were carried out by selecting representative literature studies so as to optimize the amount of these components for the optimum improvement in composite mechanical and gas barrier properties, to quantify the effect of individual components on the composite properties, and to be able to predict these properties beforehand for such kind of apolar polymer systems. The selected studies used montmorillonite-layered silicate with octadecyltrimethyl, dioctadecyldimethyl, and trioctadecylmethyl ammonium modifications ionically attached to the silicate surface. The filler dispersion in these selected studies had different degrees of intercalation and exfoliation, however, complete exfoliation of the filler platelets was never achieved. Apart from that, the filler alignment was completely random. The considered polyolefin systems were processed using similar conditions so as to avoid any differences in performance due to processing conditions. Table 1 describes the oxygen permeation properties of the polyethylene nanocomposites22 as a function of the factors used in the factorial design. The lower and upper values of volume fraction of the silicate were 1 and 2.8%, whereas the limits of cation exchange capacity of the filler were 680 and 880 µeq−1. Similarly, the number of octadecyl chains in the ammonium modification was between 2 and 3. Cation exchange capacity and number of octadecyl chains were chosen along with filler volume fraction as factors for the factorial design due to their impact on the filler ability to delaminate in the polymer matrix under shear at high temperature. The analysis of the experimental oxygen permeation data by factorial design led to a Pareto chart of standardized effects for oxygen permeation as shown in Figure 1. Volume fraction of the silicate was observed to be most significant statistically, whereas, CEC though was significant in effect, but lowest in magnitude. It thus indicated that increasing the amount of inorganic volume fraction would affect the permeation much more significantly than using clays of higher CEC or surface modifications with higher chain density. None of the two-factor or multi-factor interactions in between the components were found significant, thus, reducing the model to a linear one. Figure 2 also details the estimated effects and coefficients for oxygen permeation. A very low p value for all the three factors in the design confirmed the statistical significance of these factors. An R2 value of 99.57% confirmed the satisfactory quality of the fit. Combination of the estimated coefficients for oxygen permeation with the factors used to generate the design, following equation, could be generated to quantitatively predict the oxygen permeation performance of the composites as: Pc=76.42-5NC18-0.013CEC-6.67Vinorg Figure 1.
Pareto chart showing the statistical importance of the factors used to generate the factorial design for oxygen permeation modeling. Figure 2.
Estimated effects and coefficients for oxygen permeation modeling using the factorial design. Table 1.
Oxygen permeation values of the PE nanocomposites as a function of the factors of the factorial design
Sr. no. Number of chains in the modification CEC of silicate, µeq.g−1 Inorganic volume fraction Oxygen permeation, cm3.µm/m2. d.mmHg
1 3 680 2.8 35
2 2 880 1.0 49
3 2 880 2.8 37
4 2 680 1.0 51
5 3 680 1.0 46
6 3 880 1.0 44
7 3 880 2.8 31
8 2 680 2.8 39
CEC: cation exchange capacity; PE: polyethylene.

were Pc is the oxygen permeation through the composite films in the units of cm3 .µm/m2.d.mmHg, NC18 is the number of octadecyl chains in the silicate modification, CEC is the cation exchange capacity of the silicate substrate (µeq.g−1), and Vinorg is the inorganic filler volume fraction. In order to validate the model equation, the above equation was applied to calculate the oxygen permeation through the composites with NC18 of 1, CEC of 680 µeq.g−1, Vinorg of 2.8 and NC18 of 1, CEC of 900 µeq.g−1, Vinorg of 2.8. The predicted values of 43.9 and 42.0 cm3.µm/m2.d.mmHg, respectively, for these composites were very near to the respective experimental values of 44 and 44 cm3.µm/m2.d.mmHg,22 indicating the accuracy of the model to predict the oxygen permeation properties using the generated equation.

Table 2 elaborates the tensile modulus of the polyethylene layered silicate nanocomposites as a function of the factors of the design.23 The range of the upper and lower limits of the design factors (CEC and NC18) was also extended as compared to the oxygen permeation. Figure 3 shows the Pareto chart indicating the relative statistical importance of design factors for enhancing the tensile modulus of the polymer. Similar to oxygen permeation, all the three factors were important, however, the number of octadecyl chains in the surface modification as well as filler volume fraction had much higher significance than the CEC of the mineral. In this case also, no two or three factor interactions were present among the factors. The importance of number of octadecyl chains in the modification and the inorganic volume fraction is also evident from the estimated effects and coefficients for tensile modulus detailed in Figure 4. P values of 0.009 and 0.011 for these factors indicate their statistical significance, whereas higher p value of 0.061 for CEC confirmed its comparatively lesser significance. The following equation for the tensile modulus prediction of the nanocomposites was generated: Ec=784.17+55NC18+0.19CEC+58.33Vinorg were Ec is the tensile modulus. Application of above equation to calculate the modulus of composites with NC18 of 2, CEC of 1000 µeq.g−1, Vinorg of 3 and NC18 of 4, CEC of 900 µeq.g−1, Vinorg of 3 predicted the values of 1248 and 1339 MPa, respectively, which deviated insignificantly from the respective experimental values of 1260 and 1360 MPa for these composites,23 indicating the accuracy of the model to predict the properties. Figure 5 also represents the linear interactions between the three factors of the factorial design for the modeling of oxygen permeation and tensile modulus. Figure 3.
Pareto plot for representing the factorial design factors and their statistical importance for the modeling of tensile modulus. Figure 4.
Estimated effects and coefficients for tensile modulus modeling of the polyethylene nanocomposites using factorial design. Figure 5.
Interactions plots for (a) oxygen permeation and (b) tensile modulus modeling of polyethylene nanocomposites using factorial design. Table 2.
Tensile modulus values of the PE nanocomposites as a function of the factors of the factorial design
Sr. no. Number of chains in the modification CEC of silicate, µeq.g−1 Inorganic volume fraction Tensile modulus, MPa
1 1 680 1.0 1590
2 3 680 1.0 1670
3 1 1000 1.0 1786
4 3 1000 1.0 1895
5 1 680 2.8 1796
6 3 680 2.8 1942
7 1 1000 2.8 2016
8 3 1000 2.8 2095
CEC: cation exchange capacity; PE: polyethylene.

Figures 6 and 7 demonstrate the contour and surface plots for both oxygen permeation as well as tensile modulus, respectively. These plots represent the oxygen permeation and tensile modulus variation as a function of two factors of the design, while holding the third factor constant. The plots pictorially represent the boundaries of the generated factorial models in order to predict the modeled properties in composites with different permutations of the design factors anywhere in the modeled region. The surface plots are planar in nature owing to the linearity of the generated models. In comparison with the conventional models, the generated factorial models represent accurate means to predict the nanocomposite properties, where the prediction is based on a small set of experimental results and no assumptions are being made to generate the models. Figure 6.
(a) Contour and (b) surface plots depicting the oxygen permeation prediction as a function of factors of the factorial design. Figure 7.
(a) Contour and (b) surface plots depicting the tensile modulus prediction of polyethylene nanocomposites as a function of factors of the factorial design.

Further insights into the modeling and prediction of the properties of polyethylene layered silicate nanocomposite were gained through mixture designs. The mixture designs deal with the components of the nanocomposite system as compared to factors in the factorial design, and the synergistic combination of the information from the two models provides further understanding of the system behavior. The components considered for the mixture design were amounts of polymer (P), inorganic filler (I), and the surface modification (M). The amount of surface modification correlates to the number of octadecyl chains in the surface modification in the earlier discussed factorial design. A constrained mixture was generated with the constraints set on the polymer from 84 to 100%, inorganic from 0 to 11%, and the corresponding filler modification from 0 to 5% of the total weight of the composite, and the resulting ternary simplex design plot is shown in Figure 8 as the dotted line. The dots in the design region correspond to the experimental information fed into the design at this particular composition of components in order to generate the mixture model. The experimental values for the responses like oxygen permeation as well as tensile modulus of the composites are detailed in Table 3.22,23 It was observed in the regression for mixtures design that for both oxygen permeation as well as tensile modulus, a two-way interaction between the polymer and the inorganic filler fraction was also significant apart from individual components polymer, organic modification, and inorganic filler being statistically important. This led to non-linear response from the model as indicated in the surface and contour plots for the oxygen permeation and tensile modulus in Figures 9 and 10, respectively. By combining together the estimated coefficients for tensile modulus, the following equation could be generated for oxygen permeation as well as tensile modulus prediction: Pc=0.55MP+9.71MI-2.53MM-0.12MP*MI Ec=9.88MP+88.31MI-83.44MM-1.19MP*MI where MP is the weight percent of polymer, MM is the weight percent of organic modification, and MI is the weight percent of inorganic filler. Figure 8.
Simplex mixture design indicating the region (dotted lines) in which oxygen permeation and tensile modulus properties were modeled. Figure 9.
(a) Surface and (b) contour plots representing the non-linear models obtained for the prediction of oxygen permeation. Figure 10.
(a) Surface and (b) contour plots showing the tensile modulus prediction as a function of components of the mixture design. Table 3.
Tensile modulus and oxygen permeation through the non-compatibilized PE nanocomposites as a function of various amounts of the components of the mixture design
Sr. no. Polymer Inorganic Modification Tensile modulus, MPa Oxygen permeation, cm3.µm/m2 .d.mmHg
1 100.00 0.00 0.00 1020 54
2 89.19 10.81 0.00 1070 40
3 83.95 10.81 5.24 1360 31
4 91.98 5.41 2.62 1250 35
5 95.99 2.70 1.31 1060 49
6 87.96 8.11 3.93 1380 33
CEC: cation exchange capacity; PE: polyethylene.

Though the factorial and mixtue designs for the prediction of nanocomposite properties are accurate in prediction, however, are limted to the components selected to generate the model. Any new component added to the system would change the weight fraction as well as interactions between the components, thus requiring the generation of a new model. On the other hand, these models are very straight forward, so, generating a new model is not cumbersome. As a case study, functionalization of the non-polar matrix by the use of commonly used compatibilizers is performed in order to increase the polarity of the system and hence alter the organic–inorganic interface. As the addition of compatibilizer changes the system, a change in the model components is necessary to predict the composite behavior accurately. Table 4 describes the mechanical and gas barrier properties of the nanocomposites as a function of new mixture design components. The new mixture design for oxygen permeation and tensile modulus modeling used polymer matrix (80 to 100% of total weight), organically modified montmorillonite (0–12% of total weight), and polyethylene block poly(ethylene glycol) compatibilizer (0–8% of total weight) as mixture components (simplex design plot of Figure 11). The regression of the experimental data led to the following models for oxygen permeation and tensile modulus of the composites: Pc=0.57MP-1.35MOM-0.43Mcompat Ec=9.42MP-43.18MOM-37.28Mcompat where MP is the weight percent of polymer, MOM is the weight percent of organic modification, and MCompat is the weight percent of inorganic compatibilizer. The generated models were linear in nature as any two-way interaction between the models components was absent. This is also depicted in the surface and contour plots for oxygen permeation and tensile modulus shown in Figures 12 and 13, respectively. By following the predictions in these surface and contour plots, it is thus possible to optimize the amount of the various components in order to achieve the required performance levels in the composites. Thus, the generated model equations along with surface and contour plots represent much more accurate tools to predict the performance of polymer nanocomposites, the behavior of which is otherwise difficult to be predicted by the conventional methods. These methods are flexible and can be tuned according to the requirement. Figure 11.
Simplex mixture design for the modeling of oxygen permeation and tensile modulus of compatibilized polyethylene nanocomposites. Figure 12.
(a) Surface and (b) contour plots representing the prediction of oxygen permeation of the compatibilized polyethylene nanocomposites as a function of components of the mixture design. Figure 13.
(a) Surface and (b) contour plots demonstrating the prediction of tensile modulus of the compatibilized polyethylene nanocomposites as a function of components of the mixture design. Table 4.
Tensile modulus and oxygen permeation through the compatibilized PE nanocomposites as a function of various amounts of the components of the mixture design
Sr. no. Polymer Organically modified filler Compatibilizer Tensile modulus, MPa Oxygen permeation, cm3.µm/m2.d.mmHg
1 100 0 0 1020 54
2 93 0 7 1060 53
3 88 12 0 1270 37
4 81 12 7 1620 24

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Modeling and accurate prediction of the nanocomposite properties is difficult due to the complex morphology containing varying degrees of filler delamination and alignment. The interfacial interaction between the filler and the polymer may also not be optimum. The conventional models used to predict these properties are based on the simple assumptions that may not hold necessarily true especially in the case of apolar nanocomposites. As an alternative, the modeling and prediction of the oxygen barrier as well as tensile modulus of the polyethylene nanocomposites was achieved through various factorial and mixtures design models generated using DoE. The models were generated from a small set of experimental values and were thus not based on any unrealistic assumption. The models could be used to quantify the effect of various factors like structure of surface modification, filler volume fraction, and the cation exchange capacity along with composite components like amount of polymer, filler, compatibilizer, etc. on the composite properties. Along with that, the interactions of these factors and components with each other were also quantified. The validation of the models was also achieved by comparing the predicted values with the measured results, thus, confirming their accuracy in property prediction. The surface and contour plots generated from the model equations further help to define the modeling space in which different combinations of the model components can be considered in order to achieve the optimum set of composite properties.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
